captions.text: Good morning Hank, it's Tuesday.

So I'm back on the set of the Paper Towns
movie, but over the last, like, 100 hours,

you and me and the Katherine and both of our
parents, uh, had norovirus, which is a virus

with this amazing superpower. It can make
a human being stay on or near a toilet for,
like, 12 to 24 hours.

Side-note, Hank: Why don't fictional characters
ever get sick? Like why is Captain Ahab never

like "Uuuh, god, I've got the worst head cold
and my throat is very scratchy and I just

want to stay in my bunk but if I don't get
up and try to find the white whale, human

beings will never learn about nature's complete
indifference to them, so I guess I'll go to
work."?

Anyway, while I was horrifically ill, I kept
on wondering who exactly was responsible for

my norovirus. The thing is, Hank, you get
norovirus almost all the time by eating the
poop of someone who already has it.

Now, you only have to eat, like, .00001 grams
in order to get norovirus, but it is - I,

I want to emphasize this: someone else's poop.
Now, the clear Patient Zero in our family

is my daughter Alice; five days before Thanksgiving
she awoke from a nap and promptly vomited

all over her father, but I didn't get sick
then.

I mention this only because it leads to the
uncomfortable awareness that in all likelihood,

all of us have eaten the poop of everyone
we love. I guess except if it's an Internet

relationship. Man, Internet friendships are
the best! The next time someone says to me,

like "Oh, your Internet friendships aren't
real," I'll be like, "Listen, if your construction

of reality involves necessarily eating poop,
then I'm going to stay right here in my land
of fiction."

Anyway, this poop eating business is great
stuff to think about when you're already extremely

queasy from norovirus, but the other thing
I kept thinking is that my beautiful one-year-old

daughter whose poop had started this whole
Thanksgiving family catastrophe was going
to be OK.

Like, norovirus is almost never fatal in kids
in the U.S., but around the world, it causes

more than 200,000 child deaths per year. And
most of those kids die for want of clean water

and oral re-hydration solution that costs,
like, 50 cents. Alice got PediaLyte, that's

the only difference between, "Haha, what a
funny family Thanksgiving story," and the

greatest personal disaster I can imagine.
And whatever Alice grows up to do - whatever

any of us grow up to do - let's remember all
those times that everything rested on 50 cents

of PediaLyte or refrigerated penicillin or
access to clean water. Now, of course, the

actual process of getting oral re-hydration
solutions to the kids who need it is, like

everything else in global health and poverty,
fiendishly complicated, but I don't think

we should let that complexity stand in our
way or intimidate us.

Yes, it is hard, and yes, there are failures,
but organizations from Save the Children to

Water.org to countless local charities are
helping to decrease child mortality.

Hank, I am in no way grateful for my brush
with norovirus, but it's helpful to think

about as we head into Project for Awesome
season. The world is a profoundly unjust place;

it always has been and I imagine it always
will be, but that doesn't absolve us of our

responsibility to look directly at problems
even when they are painful to look at and

to try our best to do something to decrease
world suck.

So Hank: I'm sorry that you ate Alice's poop,
or possibly my poop; somebody's poop, anyway.

But here's to the hope of getting better,
both individually and as a species. Hank,
I'll see you on Friday.

title: What You Eat Of Those You Love

comments.text:
> wonders why fictional characters never get sick
> wrote a book about a fictional character who was chronically sick

i kid. although, i feel like i've come across a fair number of sick 
characters while reading. not so much in high fantasy or sci-fi, but in a 
lot of the (at least more recently written) books i've read with more 
mundane plots feature a main character getting a stomach bug or the like at 
some point. it doesn't tend to get dwelled on, however, probably because it 
doesn't usually impact the plot much other than slow it down some. you 
can't often do much when you're sick.﻿

comments.text:
A possible transfer mechanism is if the virus could become airborne from 
poop, then if your keep toothbrushes in your bathroom where people who have 
norovirus also use to poop, then when they flush the viruses become 
airborne, land on the toothbrushes, and get introduced into the oral cavity 
connected to the body interior, known as the mouth.﻿

comments.author: Sondos turkistani

comments.text:
Norovirus is ridiculously virulent, I've also had a family nightmare from 
it. One time, my mom got norovirus at a restaurant, she ended up having to 
go to the ER for fluids. Over the next couple of days, my dad got it 
(coincidentally while they were both sick, the dog got some sort of stomach 
bug and ended up in the doggy hospital for IV fluids). A few days later, I 
contracted the norovirus and ended up in the ER, also due to dehydration. A 
couple days later, my sister comes over, thinking she's in the clear from 
the virus, and uses the bathroom while she's here. That night, she started 
vomiting and ended up in the ER too. Over the next couple of days, her 
husband and children had all contracted norovirus as well. The kids were 
sick a lot longer, but the symptoms were less severe.
Since then, if anyone in the family gets queasy or vomits, we all almost 
break down crying in fears of norovirus. lol﻿

comments.text:
My local pharmacy sells ORS.  It's £1.50, which is about $2.30.  This seems 
like a bit of a bargain, but when you realise that ORS was invented by the 
WHO to cure international problems of rehydration after gastrointestinal 
conditions, and that it's great because it is sugar, salt and water, even 
1.50 is really taking the piss.

Somewhere, a business person has spotted that ORS is an open recipe, 
without copyright or patent, or limitations on use, and that it works, and 
has packaged it just because they can.  That kind of profiteering off of 
good work by WHO pisses me off somewhat.﻿

comments.author: stellarfirefly

comments.text:
All of my kids were born via c-section -- the first after hours of trying 
the old-fashioned way.

It's chilling to think that I would have lost the people that I love the 
most without modern medicine.  My wife and first child would have died.  
Numbers two and three would have never been conceived.

So where would I be now?  A bitter old man pining for his lost love?

No, I would be dead, too.  Modern medicine has saved me a few times, too.﻿

comments.text:
It's okay John. According to the CDC and Mayo Clinic you didn't HAVE to eat 
poop to get Norovirus. Just sharing utensils can spread it. Also it's 
resistant to heat, cold, and most disinfectants. So you can clean your 
forks and counters and still spread it. Apparently if Norovirus wants you 
it WILL get you. Unless you clean your stuff with a strong bleach solution. 
Then you might be safe.﻿

comments.author: mysticshadow2003

comments.text:
Sorry John, but it's not just poop that spreads norovirus. It's also spread 
via person to person contact and aerosolization. This is why cruse ships 
have everyone sanitize like mad and my house was cleaned to within an inch 
of its proverbial life several years ago. A tiny bit of aerosolized vomit 
on a counter can make you sick several weeks later as immunity is 
incomplete and temporary. So clean clean clean and best of health to you.

Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norovirus ﻿

comments.author: Beki Winchel

comments.text:
Dear John Green, in your book " An Abundance of Katherines", on page 73, 
you mention this greek word " μουαοκός"( according to "Penguin"). You 
mention it when Hassan tells Colin to say the word unique in as many 
languages as he can. So, the point is that, altough you use greek language 
in the book a lot- even more if you compare it to others-and it's pretty 
cool, this one word... It doesn't exist!!!! And I'm sooo surprised!
And just so you don't think I just made it up, I'm Greek. And if you want 
the word " unique" in greek, it's " μοναδικός".
Okay, I hope this didn't seem like a hate message, it's just that I didn't 
expect it at all. It's just that when you admire someone as much as I 
admire you, you get a little bit shocked. I love the book, I really do.﻿
comments.author: Aria Hastings

comments.text:
+Adam Bierstedt That's totally possible! Between Classical Greek and Modern 
Greek, there have been a lot of sound changes. So I wouldn't be surprised 
if it was an older form.
comments.author: Tabitha DeFreitas

comments.text:
